facts.text: Jhaverchand Dahyabhai Shah died in 1916, leaving a will dated August 6, 1915.

anchor.surface_text: One Jhaverchand Dahyabhai Shah died in 1916, leaving a will, dated August 6, 1915. He was a resident of Vejalpore in the suburbs of Broach and a Ladva Shrimali Bania by caste.

facts.text: Testator was resident of Vejalpore in suburbs of Broach, Ladva Shrimali Bania by caste, professed Jain religion, believed in tenets of Swetembar Murti Pujak sect.

anchor.surface_text: He was a resident of Vejalpore in the suburbs of Broach and a Ladva Shrimali Bania by caste. He professed the Jain religion, and believed in the tenets of the Swetembar Murti Pujak sect of Jains.

facts.text: By clause 7 of the will, directed executors to spend specified amounts yearly during lifetime of niece Bai Jakore on listed religious objects.

anchor.surface_text: By cl.  7  of the will, he directed his executors to spend out of the earnings of his shop every year during the life-time of his niece, Bai Jakore, the amounts mentioned below on the following religious objects

facts.text: Bai Jakore died on May 20, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Bai Jakore on May 20, 1928, the estate vested in the residuary legatee, Bai Chanchal, daughter of Bai Jakore.

facts.text: Estate vested in residuary legatee Bai Chanchal, daughter of Bai Jakore.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Bai Jakore on May 20, 1928, the estate vested in the residuary legatee, Bai Chanchal, daughter of Bai Jakore.

facts.text: Mulchandbhai, husband of Bai Chanchal, set apart Rs. 75,000 on trust for purposes in cl. 7 and managed the trust estate.

anchor.surface_text: Mulchandbhai, husband of Bai Chanchal, set apart Rs. 75,000 on trust for the purposes mentioned in cl.  7  of the win, and began to manage the trust estate.

facts.text: Out of trust moneys, invested Rs. 8,000 in 5 per cent tax-free Government Loan, 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the trust moneys, he invested Rs. 8,000 in 5 per cent tax-free Government Loan, 1944-45, yielding an annual income of Rs. 400,

facts.text: Handed over loans of Rs. 4,000, Rs. 1,000, Rs. 1,000, Rs. 2,000 to four institutions discharging obligations for items 2,4,5,6 of cl.7.

anchor.surface_text: pursuant to the directions given in cl.  15  of the will, handed over loans of the face value of Rs. 4,000, Rs. 1,000, Rs. 1,000, and Rs. 2,000 respectively to four religious and charitable institutions

facts.text: On December 8, 1947, Bai Chanchal executed a trust deed for balance Rs. 67,000 and accumulation Rs. 25,796-6-8.

anchor.surface_text: On December 8, 1947, Bai Chanchal executed a trust deed in respect of the investments representing the balance amount of Rs. 67,000 and an accumulation of surplus or unexpended income amounting to Rs. 25,796-6-8.

facts.text: Trust registered as public trust under Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The trust is registered as a public trust under the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Trust deed provided unexpended Rs. 25,796-6-8 for Nivas for poor and middle-class Ladva Shrimali Jains.

anchor.surface_text: The trust deed provided that the unexpended accumulation of Rs. 25,796-6-8 should be applied for establishing, maintaining and supporting a Nivas for housing the poor and middle-class

facts.text: Nivas scheme invalid; trustees had no authority to divert funds for it; not carried into effect.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the trustees had numberauthority to divert any part of the trust fund for the purposes of the Nivas scheme. The establishment of a Nivas for housing the poor and middle-class Ladva Shrimali Jains is number one of the original objects of the trust.

facts.text: Charity Commissioner challenged validity of Nivas scheme; courts below held it invalid.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, the Nivas scheme was number carried into effect. The Charity Commissioner, Bombay challenged the validity of the Nivas scheme.

facts.text: Swamivatsal feasts given up to Samvat 1999 (1942-1943); fixed payments met.

anchor.surface_text: The Swamivatsal feasts were given, and the fixed annual payments to all the charities were duly met up to Samvat year 1999 companyresponding to 1942- 1943 A.D.

facts.text: Feasts not given due to rationing up to Samvat 2010 (1953-1954); fixed payments made.

anchor.surface_text: During the subsequent years, the fixed annual payments to the charities were duly made, but on account of rationing restrictions, the feasts companyld number be given up to Samvat year 2010 companyresponding to 1953-1954 A.D.

facts.text: Samvat 2011 (1954-1955), feast not given despite removal of rationing.

anchor.surface_text: During the Samvat year 2011 companyresponding to 1954-1955 A.D., the feast was number given in spite of the removal of rationing restrictions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erroneously disregarded Swamivatsal feast, applied funds to non-analogous objects like Sad Vidya Mandal and Sevashram Hospital not restricted to original beneficiaries or purposes.

holdings.text: Sections 55(1)(a) and 55(1)(b) do not exclude religious trusts from their operation, and they apply to all public trusts for religious and charitable purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 5  1   c  expressly excludes from its operation a trust for a religious purpose. But ss. 55 1   a  and 55 1  b  do number exclude religious trusts from their operation, and they apply to all public trusts for religious and charitable purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.55(1)(c) exclusion does not extend to (a) and (b); Ratilal invalidated only (c) for religious trusts.

holdings.text: On an application under s.55(1)(a) or s.55(1)(b) read with s.56, the Court is bound to give directions in respect of all public trusts.

anchor.surface_text: On an application either under S. 55  1   a  or s. 55  1   b  read with S. 56 2 , the Court is bound to give directions in respect of all public trusts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language applies to all public trusts without exception for religious ones except as specified.

holdings.text: In giving directions under s.56(1), the Court shall, so far as may be expedient, practicable, desirable, necessary or proper in public interest, give effect to the original intention of the author of the public trust.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 1  provides that in giving the directions, the Court shall, so far as may be expedient, practicable, desirable, necessary or proper in public interest, give effect to the original intention of the author of the trust or the object for which the trust was created.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.56(1) first part; conjunction introduces alternatives.

precedents.citation: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay and Others 1 , this Court held that a religious sect or denomination has the right guaranteed by the Constitution to manage its own affairs in matters of religion, and this includes the right to spend the trust property or its income for religion and for religious purposes and objects indicated by the founder of the trust or established by usage obtaining in a parti

precedents.case_name: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: a religious sect or denomination has the right guaranteed by the Constitution to manage its own affairs in matters of religion, and this includes the right to spend the trust property or its income for religion and for religious purposes and objects indicated by the founder of the trust or established by usage obtaining in a particular institution. To divert the trust property or funds for purposes which the Charity Commissioner or the Court considers expedient or proper, although the original objects of the founder can still be carried out, is an unwarranted encroachment on the freedom of religious institutions
precedents.cited_holding: s. 55 1 c , which contains the offending provision and the corresponding provision relating to the powers of the Court occurring in the latter part of s. 56 1 must be held to be void

precedents.citation: Ratilal Panachands case , 1 1954 S. C. R. 1055, 82 0

precedents.case_name: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: whether, having regard to Ratilal Panachands case, its income or surplus balance spendable for the purposes of the trust can be diverted for other purposes, though the original object of the trust can still be carried out

anchor.surface_text: 1 1954 S. C. R. 1055,1070-1072. b in the case of a public trust other than a trust for a religious purpose, it is number in public interest expedient, practicable, desirable, necessary or proper to carry out wholly or partially the original intention of the author of the public trust or the object for which the public trust was created and that the property or the income of the public trust or any portion thereof should be applied to any other charitable or religious object,

precedents.case_name: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: constitutional validity of the Bombay Public Trusts Act provisions on diverting religious trust funds

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the judgments and decrees passed by the Courts below are set aside. In lieu of the directions given by the Courts below, we give the following directions Out of the accumulations of the unexpended income up to the 25th October, 1956 amounting to Rs. 45,091-14-0 the trustees will set apart a reasonable sum number exceeding Rs. 5,000 as a working fund to meet current expenses. The trustees will invest the balance amount in such manner as they think fit in accordance with S. 35 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgments and decrees of courts below set aside; lower courts' scheme/directions for diversion of accumulations to Sad Vidya Mandal and Sevashram Hospital set aside; new directions issued for retention and investment of accumulations and their income to be used for original trust objects including Swamivatsal feasts.
directions: Out of the accumulations of the unexpended income up to the 25th October, 1956 amounting to Rs. 45,091-14-0 the trustees will set apart a reasonable sum number exceeding Rs. 5,000 as a working fund to meet current expenses.
The trustees will invest the balance amount in such manner as they think fit in accordance with S. 35 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

The trustees will spend and utilise every year one-half of the annual income from these investments for the charities mentioned in items 1, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12 of cl. 7 of the will of Jhaverchand Dahyabhai Shah, dated August 6, 1915 in such proportion and in such manner as the trustees think fit and proper.
The trustees will spend and utilise every year the balance one-half of the annual income of those investments for the annual Swamivatsal feast (caste-dinner) mentioned in cl. 7 of the aforesaid will.
The disbursements to be made under these directions will be in addition to the payments to be made by the trustees out of the income of the investments of the original corpus of the trust funds.

Out of the net income of the investments of the original corpus, the trustees will continue to make the annual payments to the charities mentioned in items 1, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12 of cl. 7 of the aforesaid will and will spend the balance income for giving the annual Swamivatsal feasts.

The trustees shall give the Swamivatsal feast every year as far as possible. If for some reason the feast cannot be given in any year, the amount spendable for this object in that year should be spent for giving the feast in the following years.

In the circumstances of the case, we direct that the parties will pay and bear their own costs throughout in this Court as also in the Courts below, except that the trustees will pay the sum of Rs. 64-8-0 to the Charity Commissioner and the sum of Rs. 42-10-0 to opponents Nos.
